Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: The store was packed, the line at my register snaking past the candy racks. My manager’s words echoed in my head: “Stay calm, be friendly, no matter what.” The woman in front of me was red-faced, waving a receipt, her voice rising. I forced a smile, trying to listen, but my eyes kept darting to the window. Outside, my stepbrother, Jamie, was setting up his skateboard at the top of the old, cracked ramp. He’d been talking about this trick for weeks, but the ramp was steeper than it looked, and I knew how reckless he could be. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But right now, I was trapped behind the register, expected to be the perfect cashier, patient and cheerful, even as my heart pounded with worry. The customer’s complaints blurred into the background as I watched Jamie crouch, ready to launch. I felt torn in two—should I drop everything and run to stop him, or stay and do my job? The pressure from both sides squeezed my chest, and I stood frozen, caught between the demands of family and work.
